stem: Match the following neurological findings to the most likely affected area of the brain.

rationale.correct: Left MCA: Right-sided hemiparesis and expressive aphasia are classic signs of a stroke affecting the left middle cerebral artery (MCA). These areas control motor function and language, respectively, on the contralateral side of the body.  Cerebellum: Ataxia and balance problems are commonly associated with cerebellar dysfunction. Occipital Lobe: Visual disturbances, such as hemianopia or cortical blindness, are characteristic of occipital lobe damage. Temporal Lobe: Auditory processing and memory consolidation are primarily functions of the temporal lobe, hence difficulty understanding speech.

mnemonic.name: FAST
mnemonic.description: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call 911 â€“ helps identify stroke symptoms quickly.

rationale.incorrect: Each of the incorrect pairings suggest a different location than where the neurological findings are actually originating. For example, patients experiencing right-sided weakness will not experience cerebellar dysfunction. Rather, that will be localized to the contralateral side of the brain, which is the left MCA.

questionTrap.reason: A thorough understanding of neuroanatomy and the contralateral nature of motor and sensory pathways is necessary to answer correctly.
questionTrap.commonMistake: Students may confuse the affected side of the brain with the side of the body exhibiting symptoms (contralateral vs. ipsilateral).

clinicalPearls: Time is brain: Rapid assessment and intervention are crucial in acute stroke management.
The NIHSS score is a valuable tool for quantifying neurological deficits and guiding treatment decisions.
CT head without contrast is essential to rule out hemorrhage before administering tPA.

itemContext.sbar: Patient is a 68-year-old male who presented to the ED with sudden onset right-sided weakness and aphasia approximately 2 hours ago. Last known well was this morning. NIHSS score is 18.

patient.chiefComplaint: Sudden onset of weakness on the right side of his body and difficulty speaking.
